author: Graeme Whitfield
title: North East LEP calls on Government to ensure multi-million EU funding
text:
North East LEP calls on Government to ensure multi-million EU funding 18:30, 7 Jul 2016 By Graeme Whitfield Vote Leave had pledged to maintain EU funding but neither of the Tory leadership candidates signed that letter Shares Get business news by email Andrew Hodgson of SMD Ltd in Wallsend 
The body charged with developing the North East economy is seeking assurances from the Government over the delivery of EU funding to the region. 
The North East Local Enterprise Partnership (LEP) has committed £89.5m of EU structural funding to boost growth in the region, while a further £104.5m was submitted to the Government for approval in the run up to last month’s referendum. 
The projects already approved will support more than 7,400 businesses across the North East LEP area, and also provide support and training to around 30,000 people either looking for work or trying to progress through improving their skills. 
Earlier this week, the Joseph Rowntree Foundation warned that the North East could lose up to £400m from the UK’s withdrawal from Europe, while local councils are also seeking assurances that billions of pounds of EU regeneration funding will not be lost. 
Before the referendum, the Vote Leave campaign pledged to maintain EU funding to the regions, but the 13 Tory ministers do not include either of the two candidates running for the Conservative leadership. Neither Theresa May, who campaigned to remain in the EU, nor Andrea Leadsom, who fought for Leave but did not sign the regional pledge, could be held to the pledge. 
North East LEP chair Andrew Hodgson said: “We are hopeful that these projects will be honoured by Government and deliver important support to businesses and local people before Brexit happens. 
“It is important to realise we will not be immediately losing the opportunities that EU funding has historically brought to the North East. 
“Millions of pounds of projects are still likely to go ahead, bringing new jobs and closing the skills gap in the North East. The truth is that we just don’t know yet if or when we will see changes. 
“EU funding has hugely benefitted the North East over the last few decades and we are lobbying Government for clarity and seeking assurances that any potential future funding gap will be filled. We urge the Government to provide this guidance quickly to ensure opportunities to create jobs and growth are not lost.” 
The LEP said there was “no formal Government guidance” on how much funding will be available in the future for North East businesses and organisations beyond the projects already approved.
